statement.p: Delbert traveled 258 miles on 12 gallons of gas, and Francine traveled 182 miles on 8 gallons of gas. Compute the ratio \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}} for each car.
Delbert: \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}}
Francine: \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}}

Whose car gets the better gas mileage?
?
Delbert
Francine

solution.p: Delbert: \dfrac{258}{12}= 21.5 mpg, Francine: \dfrac{182}{8}=22.75 mpg. Francine gets better mileage.

li.p: Choose two points and compute the slope (including units). (Note: Use ft for feet and use min for minutes.)
What does the slope tell us about the problem?
A) The steepness of the ski lift.
B) The increase in altitude per minute.
C) The time to rise a foot in altitude.
D) The cost of using the ski lift.

p.m: m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{700 \text{ ft}-100\text{ ft}}{4\text{ min}-0\text{ min}}= {150\ {\textstyle\frac{\rm\mathstrut ft}{\rm\mathstrut min}}}

li.p: The skiers altitude increases by 150 feet per minute.

statement.p: How does slope measure rate of change?

li.p: Find the slope of the line passing through the points (2, -3) and ( -2, -1)\text{.}
Sketch a graph of the line by hand.
A graph is shown below.

statement.p: Comment on the following calculation: The intercepts of a line are (0,3) and (5,0)\text{,} so the slope of the line is \dfrac{5}{3}\text{.}

li.p: It is true because we used two points.
It is false because \Delta x and \Delta y have opposite signs.
It is true because the values are increasing.
It is false because the slope is \dfrac{3}{5}.

solution.p: It is false because \Delta x and \Delta y have opposite signs. (The slope of the line is \dfrac{-5}{3}\text{.})

li.p: Find f (3) and f (5)\text{.}
Compute the slope of the line segment joining the points at x = 3 and x = 5\text{.}
Write an expression for the slope of the line segment joining the points at x = a and x = b\text{.}
Note: Be careful to use appropriate parentheses. Press the Preview My Answers button below to see if you are entering an appropriate expression.

statement.p: Summarize what you learned about slope in this lesson.
Delbert traveled 258 miles on 12 gallons of gas, and Francine traveled 182 miles on 8 gallons of gas. Compute the ratio \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}} for each car.
Delbert: \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}}
Francine: \dfrac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallon}}

Whose car gets the better gas mileage?
?
Delbert
Francine

solution.p: Delbert: \dfrac{258}{12}= 21.5 mpg, Francine: \dfrac{182}{8}=22.75 mpg. Francine gets better mileage.

statement.p: The weight of 12 gallons of gasoline is 67.5 pounds, and the weight of 5 gallons of water is 41.6 pounds. Compute the ratio \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}} for each liquid.
gasoline: \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}}
water: \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}}

Which liquid weighs more per gallon
?
gasoline
water

solution.p: gasoline: \dfrac{67.5}{12}= 5.625 pounds per gallon, water: \dfrac{41.6}{5}=8.32 pounds per gallon. Water weighs more per gallon.

statement.p: Which is steeper, a staircase that rises 10 feet over a horizontal distance of 4 feet, or the steps in the football stadium, which rise 20 yards over a horizontal distance of 12 yards?

Answer:
?
staircase
steps in stadium

solution.p: Staircase: \dfrac{10}{4}= 2.5\text{,} Steps: \dfrac{20}{12}\approx 1.66666666666667\text{.} The staircase is steeper.

statement.p: Compute the slope of the line through the indicated points on the graph above. On both axes, one square represents one unit.
The weight of 12 gallons of gasoline is 67.5 pounds, and the weight of 5 gallons of water is 41.6 pounds. Compute the ratio \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}} for each liquid.
gasoline: \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}}
water: \dfrac{\text{pounds}}{\text{gallon}}

Which liquid weighs more per gallon
?
gasoline
water

solution.p: gasoline: \dfrac{67.5}{12}= 5.625 pounds per gallon, water: \dfrac{41.6}{5}=8.32 pounds per gallon. Water weighs more per gallon.

statement.p: What is wrong with the following reasoning? The point (10,7) lies on the graph of a line, so the slope of the line is \dfrac{7}{10}\text{.}

li.p: The slope is \dfrac{10}{7}.
7 is not an intercept.
We need two points to compute the slope.
The line is decreasing.

solution.p: We need two points to compute the slope.

statement.p: The square base is 55 meters on each side, and the top platform is 19.5 meters on each side. Calculate the slope of the sides of the pyramid. Which pyramid is steeper, Kukulcan or the Great Pyramid (whose slope, rounded to two decimals, is 1.28)?

Answer:
?
Kukulcan
Great Pyramid

hint.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform.

solution.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform: \Delta x=\frac{1}{2}(55-19.5)= 17.75\text{,} so the slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{24}{17.75} \approx {1.35211}\text{,} which is greater than 1.28. Kukulcan is steeper.

statement.p: Suppose x represents your distance from home, in miles. Compare the meanings of the two statements x=30 and \Delta x=30\text{.}

li.p: Graph the line 4x - 2y = 8 by finding the x- and y-intercepts
x-intercept:
y-intercept:
Note: Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
Compute the slope of the line using the x-intercept and y-intercept.
Compute the slope of the line using the points (4, 4) and (1, -2)\text{.}
A graph of the line is shown below this exercise.
The x-intercept is {\left(2,0\right)} and the y-intercept is {\left(0,-4\right)}\text{.}
The slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{ + 4}{2} = 2
The slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{-2-4}{1-4}=\dfrac{-6}{-3} = 2

statement.p: How can you tell from the equation of a line whether its graph is decreasing?

li.p: Its slope is positive.
Its x-intercept is positive.
Its slope is negative.
Its x-intercept is negative.

solution.p: The graph is decreasing when its slope is negative.

A) The steepness of the ski lift.
B) The increase in altitude per minute.
C) The time to rise a foot in altitude.
D) The cost of using the ski lift.

statement.p: Comment on the following calculation: The intercepts of a line are (0,3) and (5,0)\text{,} so the slope of the line is \dfrac{5}{3}\text{.}

li.p: It is true because we used two points.
It is false because \Delta x and \Delta y have opposite signs.
It is true because the values are increasing.
It is false because the slope is \dfrac{3}{5}.

solution.p: It is false because \Delta x and \Delta y have opposite signs. (The slope of the line is \dfrac{-5}{3}\text{.})

li.p: Find f (3) and f (5)\text{.}

Note: Be careful to use appropriate parentheses. Press the Preview My Answers button below to see if you are entering an appropriate expression.

statement.p: Which is steeper, a staircase that rises 10 feet over a horizontal distance of 4 feet, or the steps in the football stadium, which rise 20 yards over a horizontal distance of 12 yards?

Answer:
?
staircase
steps in stadium

solution.p: Staircase: \dfrac{10}{4}= 2.5\text{,} Steps: \dfrac{20}{12}\approx 1.66666666666667\text{.} The staircase is steeper.

statement.p: Summarize what you learned about slope in this lesson.
How can you tell from a table of values that a function describes exponential growth?

li.p: During each equal time interval, the output increases by the same amount.
During each equal time interval, the output increases by the same factor.
During each equal time interval, the output increases as t^n.
During each equal time interval, the output increases towards an asymptote.

solution.p: During each equal time interval, the output increases by the same factor.

statement.p:
A population of 24 fruit flies triples every month.
Write a formula for the population of fruit flies after t months.
P(t)=
How many fruit flies will there be after 6 months? Note: Enter (large) numbers without any commas. That is, enter 10000 rather than 10,000.
After 3 weeks? (Assume that a month equals 4 weeks, and round your answer to the nearest whole number of flies.)
Is 5 \cdot 4^t equivalent to 20^t\text{?}

li.p: Yes, we can simplify the product.
Yes, it is exponential growth.
No, powers are performed before products.
No, it should be 9^t.

solution.p: No, powers are performed before products.

statement.p: A population triples every four years. What is its annual growth factor?

In 1999, analysts expected the number of Internet service providers to double in five years.
What was the annual growth factor for the number of Internet service providers?
Answer:
If there were 5078 Internet service providers in April 1999, estimate the number of providers in April 2000 and in April 2001.
April 2000:
April 2001:
Write a formula for I (t)\text{,} the number of Internet service providers t years after 1999.
I(t)=
Source: LA Times, Sept. 6, 1999
A population grows by 4.5% per year. What is its annual growth factor?
Describe carefully the meanings of b and r in the formulas for exponential growth.
A population decreases by 12% per year. What is its annual decay factor?
The function P(t)=P_0 b^t is decreasing if

li.p: P_0 is negative
b is negative

statement.p: Compute the slope of the line through the indicated points on the graph above. On both axes, one square represents one unit.
The graph of P(t)=P_0 b^t\text{,} where P_0 \gt 0 and b \gt 0\text{,} is always

li.p: increasing
concave up
decreasing
concave down

solution.p: concave up

statement.p: A new car begins to depreciate in value as soon as you drive it off the lot. Some models depreciate linearly, and others depreciate exponentially. Suppose you buy a new car for $20,000, and 1 year later its value has decreased to $17,000.

li.p: If the value decreased linearly, what was its annual rate of decrease?
$ per year
If the value decreased exponentially, what was its annual decay factor? What was its annual percent depreciation? %
Calculate the value of your car when it is 5 years old under each assumption, linear or exponential depreciation.
Linear: $
Exponential: $
\$3000 per year
Linear: \$5000\text{;} Exponential: \$8874

statement.p: Explain the difference between constant slope and constant growth factor.
Use the ratio method to find an exponential function whose graph includes the points (1, 20) and (3, 125)\text{.}
You have written a system of equations to fit an exponential function through two points. What is the next step?

li.p: A) Calculate the slope.
B) Subtract one equation from the other.
C) Divide one equation by the other.
D) Take the log of both sides.

solution.p: Divide one equation by the other.

statement.p: The number of earthquakes that occur worldwide is a decreasing exponential function of their magnitude on the Richter scale. Between 2000 and 2005, there were 7480 earthquakes of magnitude 5 and 793 earthquakes of magnitude 6. (Source: National Earthquake Information Center, U.S. Geological Survey)

li.p: Find a formula for the number of earthquakes, N(m)\text{,} in terms of their magnitude.
Do not use any commas: For example, instead of 10,000 enter simply 10000.
It is difficult to keep an accurate count of small earthquakes. Use your formula to estimate the number of magnitude 1 earthquakes that occurred between 2000 and 2005.
How many earthquakes of magnitude 8 occurred?

statement.p: Which statement is true?

li.p: A) The doubling time of a population depends on its initial value.
B) An increasing exponential function has a constant doubling time.
C) The doubling time is twice the percent growth rate.
D) The doubling time is half the percent growth rate.

solution.p: An increasing exponential function has a constant doubling time.

statement.p: In 2005, the population of Uganda was 26.9 million people and was growing by 3.2% per year.

li.p: Write a formula for the population of Uganda as a function of years since 2005.
P(t)= million
How long will it take the population of Uganda to double?
years
Use your formula from part (a) to verify the doubling time for three doubling periods.
P(t) = 26.9(1.032)^t million
22 years

P(0) = 26.9\text{;} P(22)\approx 53.8\text{,} i.e., P(22)\approx 2\cdot P(0)\text{;} P(44)\approx 107.6\text{,} i.e., P(44)\approx 2\cdot P(22)\text{;} P(66)\approx 215.1\text{,} i.e., P(66)\approx 2\cdot P(44)

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2022-12-02T17:04:50-05:00 ### A recent stable commit (2020-08-09): ### 98f21740783f166a773df4dc83cab5293ab63a4a ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(5.5.9) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context()->variables->add(t=>"Real"); $f = Formula("26.9*1.032**t"); $dt = Compute("log(2)/log(1.032)")->with( tolType => 'absolute', tolerance => .5, );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML In 2005, the population of Uganda was 26.9 million people and was growing by 3.2% per year.
a. Write a formula for the population of Uganda as a function of years since 2005.
[`P(t)=`][_]{$f}{12} million
a. How long will it take the population of Uganda to double?
[_]{$dt}{2} years
a. Use your formula from part (a) to verify the doubling time for three doubling periods.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. [`P(t) = 26.9(1.032)^t`] million
a. [`22`] years
a. [`P(0) = 26.9\text{;}`] [`P(22)\approx 53.8\text{,}`] i.e., [`P(22)\approx 2\cdot P(0)\text{;}`] [`P(44)\approx 107.6\text{,}`] i.e., [`P(44)\approx 2\cdot P(22)\text{;}`] [`P(66)\approx 215.1\text{,}`] i.e., [`P(66)\approx 2\cdot P(44)`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: The formula P(t)=P_0 2^{t/D} tells us that:

li.p: P(t) is twice the initial value.
After 2 years, P(t)=D.
After D years, P(t)=2P_0.
P(t) grows by a factor of D.

solution.p: After D years, P(t)=2P_0\text{.}

statement.p: At its current rate of growth, the population of Mexico will double in 36.8 years. What is its annual percent rate of growth?
Answer: %
What is wrong with the following reasoning? The point (10,7) lies on the graph of a line, so the slope of the line is \dfrac{7}{10}\text{.}

li.p: The slope is \dfrac{10}{7}.
7 is not an intercept.
We need two points to compute the slope.
The line is decreasing.

solution.p: We need two points to compute the slope.

statement.p: How can you find the growth factor for an exponential function when you know its doubling time?
The half-life of DDT is 15 years. This means that:

li.p: A) 30 pounds of DDT dissolve in one year.
B) 100 pounds of DDT dissolve in 30 years.
C) After 30 years, 100 pounds of DDT is reduced to 25 pounds.
D) Each half-pound of DDT takes 15 years to dissolve.

solution.p: After 30 years, 100 pounds of DDT is reduced to 25 pounds.

statement.p: Alcohol is eliminated from the body at a rate of 15% per hour.

li.p: Write a decay formula for the amount of alcohol remaining in the body, using A_0 for the initial amount of alcohol. [Note: Enter A to get A_0\text{.}].
What is the half-life of alcohol in the body?
hours
4.3 hours

statement.p: Cesium-137, with a half-life of 30 years, is one of the most dangerous by-products of nuclear fission. What is the annual decay rate for cesium-137?
Answer: %
How can you use the half-life to sketch a graph of an exponential function?
The following graph shows the % battery charge on a cell phone as a function of the number of hours after midnight. The owner keeps the phone charging while she sleeps at night.

li.p: How many hours does it take to charge the phone?
Answer:
What time does the user begin recharging the phone each day?
This function is periodic, meaning that it repeats itself over and over.
How many hours does it take to repeat itself completely?
Answer:
It takes 6 hours to fully rechage the phone.
The user begins recharging the phone at 6:00 P.M. each day.
It takes 24 hours for this function to repeat itself.

statement.p: The period of each function below is a whole number. Find the period of each function.
Period =
Period =
Period =

li.p: The period is 4.
The period is 5.
The period is 3.

statement.p: Suppose a person boards at the bottom of a Ferris Wheel and rides around for 35 seconds. See the graph below.

At bottom left is a diagram of the Ferris Wheel, where the triangle shows the position of rider. Using the sliders at right, you can adjust things like:
the wheels radius
the height of the loading platform (which moves the wheel up or down)
the period of the wheel.
The graph above shows the riders height above the ground (in meters) as they ride on the wheel for 35 seconds.

li.p: For a person riding a Ferris Wheel, what causes a vertical stretch for the graph?

Answer:
?
Changing the radius of the wheel
Changing the platform height
Changing the period
What causes a vertical shift for the graph?

Answer:
?
Changing the radius of the wheel
Changing the platform height
Changing the period
What causes a horizontal stretch for the graph?

Answer:
?
Changing the radius of the wheel
Changing the platform height
Changing the period

hint.p: Use the slider to increase the time completely. Then change the sliders for the radius, platform height and period and see what happens to the graph.

li.p: A vertical stretch occurs when the radius of the wheel changes. This should make sense because if the wheel is larger, the rider will reach a different maximum height.
A vertical shift occurs when the boarding height is increased. The whole wheel moves up, causing the graph to shift vertically.
A horizontal stretch occurs when the period of the wheel changes. If it takes longer for the wheel to make a complete rotation, then the riders height function will be stretched horizontally.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2022-12-02T17:04:51-05:00 ### A recent stable commit (2020-08-09): ### 98f21740783f166a773df4dc83cab5293ab63a4a ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(5.6.3) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "parserPopUp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $vertStretch=PopUp(["?","Changing the radius of the wheel","Changing the platform height","Changing the period"],"Changing the radius of the wheel"); $vertShift=PopUp(["?","Changing the radius of the wheel","Changing the platform height","Changing the period"],"Changing the platform height"); $horizontalStretch=PopUp(["?","Changing the radius of the wheel","Changing the platform height","Changing the period"],"Changing the period");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Suppose a person boards at the bottom of a Ferris Wheel and rides around for [`35`] seconds. See the graph below.
At bottom left is a diagram of the Ferris Wheel, where the triangle shows the position of rider. Using the sliders at right, you can adjust things like: * the wheel's _radius_
* the _height_ of the loading platform (which moves the wheel up or down)
* the _period_ of the wheel.
The graph above shows the rider's height above the ground (in meters) as they ride on the wheel for [`35`] seconds.
a. For a person riding a Ferris Wheel, what causes a vertical stretch for the graph?
Answer: [_]{$vertStretch}{5}
a. What causes a vertical shift for the graph?
Answer: [_]{$vertShift}{5}
a. What causes a horizontal stretch for the graph?
Answer: [_]{$horizontalStretch}{5}
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Use the slider to increase the time completely. Then change the sliders for the _radius_, _platform height_ and _period_ and see what happens to the graph.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A vertical stretch occurs when the radius of the wheel changes. This should make sense because if the wheel is larger, the rider will reach a different maximum height.
a. A vertical shift occurs when the boarding height is increased. The whole wheel moves _up_, causing the graph to shift vertically.
a. A horizontal stretch occurs when the period of the wheel changes. If it takes longer for the wheel to make a complete rotation, then the rider's height function will be stretched horizontally.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: The graph above shows a periodic function. Use it to determine the values below.
Period =
Amplitude =
Midline: y =

li.p: Period = 4
Amplitude = 1.5
Midline: y =-3.5

statement.p: A person rides a Ferris Wheel, boarding it at a height of 10 feet at the 6 Oclock position. The wheel has a diameter of 60 feet, and it completes a revolution every 20 minutes.
Let f(t) represent the persons height (in feet) above the ground, as a function of t\text{,} the number of minutes theyve been riding.
Complete the table of values below for the function f\text{.}
You found the heights in the following table:
In the graph below, move the points to match those from your table above. If the points are placed correctly, the graph of y = f(t) will appear.

Did the graph appear?
?
yes
no
What is the amplitude of the function?
Answer: feet
What is the period of the function?
Answer: minutes
What is the equation of the midline?
Answer:

li.p: The amplitude is 30 feet.
The period is 20 minutes.
The midline is: y = 40

statement.p: The square base is 55 meters on each side, and the top platform is 19.5 meters on each side. Calculate the slope of the sides of the pyramid. Which pyramid is steeper, Kukulcan or the Great Pyramid (whose slope, rounded to two decimals, is 1.28)?

Answer:
?
Kukulcan
Great Pyramid

hint.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform.

solution.p: The horizontal change \Delta x is half the difference between the sides of the base and of the top platform: \Delta x=\frac{1}{2}(55-19.5)= 17.75\text{,} so the slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{24}{17.75} \approx {1.35211}\text{,} which is greater than 1.28. Kukulcan is steeper.

statement.p: A person boards a Ferris Wheel at the 6 Oclock position. The graph shows the persons height above the ground (in feet) as they ride the Ferris Wheel. Here, the horizontal axis represents time (in minutes).
Use the graph to help answer the questions that follow.

li.p: What is the radius of the wheel?
Answer: feet
How high is the center of the wheel?
Answer: feet
How long does it take to make one complete revolution on the wheel?
Answer: minutes
The radius is 60 feet.
The center of the wheel is 80 feet above the ground.
It takes 15 minutes to make a complete revolution.

webwork-reps.pg:
############################################# ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2022-12-02T17:04:52-05:00 ### A recent stable commit (2020-08-09): ### 98f21740783f166a773df4dc83cab5293ab63a4a ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ############################################# ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(5.6.8) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGgraphmacros.pl", "PGcourse.pl", ); COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt');
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $radius=Real(60); $midline=Real(80); $period=Real(15); $gr=init_graph(-5,-20,45,200, axes=>[0,0], grid=>[10,11], size=>[400,400] ); add_functions($gr, "-60*cos(2*pi/15*x)+80 for x in <0,45> using color:red and weight:2");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML A person boards a Ferris Wheel at the [`6`] _O'clock_ position. The graph shows the person's height above the ground (in feet) as they ride the Ferris Wheel. Here, the horizontal axis represents time (in minutes).
Use the graph to help answer the questions that follow.
>> [@image(insertGraph($gr), width=>600)@]* <<
a. What is the radius of the wheel?
Answer: [_]{$radius}{10} feet
a. How high is the center of the wheel?
Answer: [_]{$midline}{10} feet
a. How long does it take to make one complete revolution on the wheel?
Answer: [_]{$period}{10} minutes
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. The radius is [$radius] feet.
a. The center of the wheel is [$midline] feet above the ground.
a. It takes [$period] minutes to make a complete revolution.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p: Suppose x represents your distance from home, in miles. Compare the meanings of the two statements x=30 and \Delta x=30\text{.}

li.p: Graph the line 4x - 2y = 8 by finding the x- and y-intercepts
x-intercept:
y-intercept:
Note: Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
Compute the slope of the line using the x-intercept and y-intercept.
Compute the slope of the line using the points (4, 4) and (1, -2)\text{.}
A graph of the line is shown below this exercise.
The x-intercept is {\left(2,0\right)} and the y-intercept is {\left(0,-4\right)}\text{.}
The slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{ + 4}{2} = 2
The slope is m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}= \dfrac{-2-4}{1-4}=\dfrac{-6}{-3} = 2

statement.p: How can you tell from the equation of a line whether its graph is decreasing?

li.p: Its slope is positive.
Its x-intercept is positive.
Its slope is negative.
Its x-intercept is negative.

solution.p: The graph is decreasing when its slope is negative.
